documents.title: What is the Right to Withdraw (RTW) process?
documents.content:
The customer can withdraw from the agreement within 14 days of the loan being funded. This period begins the day after the loan is funded. Once a customer has withdrawn, they have 30 days to repay the balance. This balance will accrue daily interest at a rate of 0.8% per day, based on the outstanding principal.
You should set a repayment date within the 30-day period via the Accounts tab in the Schedule section. Once the loan has been settled, raise a "Customer Service -- Withdrawal from Agreement" task. After full RTW compliance, the loan entry will be removed from the customer's credit file with the credit reference agencies.

documents.title: I've received the transaction response: "Transaction declined by authorization system" -- what does this mean?

documents.title: The customer says the application was made fraudulently and not by them. What should I do?
documents.content:
When taking the initial details of an alleged fraudulent application, make sure to record the following information on the system:
â€¢	Contact telephone number
â€¢	Email address
â€¢	Whether they recognise or hold the current bank details on the account
If the customer does not recognise the bank account, advise them to report it to their bank and request an investigation into how the account was opened in their name. We will need a copy of the letter the bank issues once their investigation is complete before we can consider closing the account.
If the bank account does belong to the customer, we will still require written confirmation from the bank stating that fraudulent transactions occurred and were investigated. In such cases, we expect the bank to reimburse the customer, who can then return the funds to us. We will also require a letter from the bank in order to write off any remaining interest.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What is the Debt Respite Scheme?
documents.content:
The Debt Respite Scheme, also known as Breathing Space, is a UK government initiative that offers individuals temporary protection from creditors while they seek debt advice or mental health treatment.
There are two types:
â€¢	Standard Breathing Space -- lasts for 60 days
â€¢	Mental Health Crisis Breathing Space -- lasts for the duration of the treatment, plus an additional 30 days, even if this exceeds 60 days
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What stage should I use for an account under the Debt Respite Scheme?
documents.content:
Use On Hold -- 2 Months for a standard breathing space
Use On Hold -- Vulnerable Customer for a Mental Health breathing space

In both cases, make sure to add a task to review the account in 60 days. The Insolvency Service typically informs us when the hold expires.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: Is interest added while the account is in Breathing Space?
documents.content: No. Interest, fees, and charges are frozen while the account is in Breathing Space.

documents.title: Right to Withdraw (RTW) Process
documents.content:
If a customer wishes to withdraw from their loan agreement, they must inform us within 14 days of the loan being funded. This 14-day period starts the day after the loan is funded.
The customer can notify us of their intention to withdraw either verbally or in writing.
The customer has 30 days from the date they notify us of their intention to withdraw to repay:
The amount borrowed, plus
The daily interest accrued up to the date the repayment is made.
Ask the customer to confirm the exact date they intend to make the repayment.
Create a new payment schedule for that date.
Set yourself a follow-up task on the same date to check whether the payment was made and follow up if necessary.
If the Customer Canâ€™t Confirm a Date schedule the repayment for the 30th day after the withdrawal notification.
If the customer is unhappy with a card payment being scheduled, switch the payment method to bank transfer to avoid automated card collection attempts.
The balance will remain due, and the customer will continue to receive payment reminders as part of the usual communication cycle. If unpaid, the account will flow into the standard collections strategy.

documents.title: Interest Query
documents.content:
Process Overview

Refer to the customerâ€™s original loan schedule and explain the Total Amount Payable (TAP) they agreed to at the start of their loan.
Let them know that this amount reflects what they would repay if all payments were made on time, with no changes to their repayment dates.
If the TAP has increased due to changes in payment behaviour, explain why:
Interest accrues daily at a rate of 0.8% on the outstanding principal.
Any missed payments, changes in payday, or reduced payments may lead to an increase in the total interest charged.
Reassure them that interest is capped at 100% of the amount borrowed â€” this is a rule set by our regulator, the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA).
Help the customer understand how they can reduce their interest:

The more they pay, the less interest is charged, as the balance decreases.
Even nominal payments (small amounts) can help reduce the interest if made within the interest-charging period.
If the customer expresses frustration (e.g., â€œYouâ€™re ripping me offâ€ or â€œYouâ€™re like loan sharksâ€), respond calmly and clearly:

We are a regulated lender, authorised by the FCA.
We follow all legal rules on interest and have clearly outlined the terms in the agreement the customer signed.
We do not charge more than the 100% cap, and customers have control over how much interest builds up by making timely or early payments.
Offer to help them explore ways to settle early or reduce their repayment burden.

documents.title: Fraud Process
documents.content:
Process Overview:

Customer confirms that the bank details are not theirs:

If a customer contacts us to say they didnâ€™t apply for the loan â€” often after receiving a default notice or spotting it on their credit file â€” follow these steps:
Verify Identity & Cross-Check Details
Ask the customer to confirm their full name, email address, contact number, and bank account details.
Compare these to whatâ€™s recorded on the account.
Outcome Based on Matching Details
If the email, phone number, and bank details match:
This likely indicates the customer, or someone close to them, made the application.
The customer would usually remain liable.
If youâ€™re uncertain, escalate to the Fraud Specialist â€“ Zoe Quick.
If any details do not match, especially the bank details:
Record the customer's correct contact details in the system for follow-up.
Advise the customer to report the loan as fraudulent to the bank used on the application.
The bank must investigate and provide a written response confirming the findings.
Hold the Account
Place the account on hold for 30 days while waiting for bank confirmation.
After 30 days or upon receipt of the bankâ€™s response, escalate to Zoe Quick for fraud investigation.
Customer Confirms All Details Are Correct â€“ But Denies Applying

If the customer confirms that all details on the loan are correct, but insists they didnâ€™t apply:
Advise Immediate External Reporting
Instruct the customer to report the incident to:
Their bank
Action Fraud
The police (to obtain a crime reference number)
Request Supporting Evidence
We require a letter from the bank confirming that the loan funds were deposited and withdrawn by a third party without the customerâ€™s consent.
This confirmation must be in writing and clearly state that the transaction was fraudulent.
Fraud Outcome Handling

Once confirmed in writing:
The customer will be expected to repay the original loan amount (principal), since the funds were received.
The business will then write off any interest that accrued.
This aligns with our policy where fraud is proven and funds are reimbursed by the bank.

documents.title: Breathing Space Workflow
documents.content:
Step 1: Identify Eligibility for Breathing Space
Trigger Event: 
â€¢	Consider breathing space if a customer discloses financial hardship, or is identified, or discloses as vulnerable.
Initial Assessment: 
â€¢	Review the customer's circumstances to determine if breathing space is suitable. Serious vulnerabilities, particularly health or mental health concerns, should be assigned to the Vulnerability Specialist (VS) - Zoe Quick.
Triggers for Referral to  Vulnerability Specialist (VS)
Please note: If the customer displays any of the following triggers, please note the account and assign to the Vulnerability Specialist. If the customer does not display any of the triggers below, then continue to step 2
Direct Disclosure of Health Conditions
â€¢	The customer mentions a diagnosed mental health or physical health condition (e.g., depression, anxiety, cancer) that affects their ability to manage finances or respond to communications.
â€¢	They discuss ongoing medical treatment or challenges that may impact their financial stability.
Mentions of Suicide or Self-Harm
â€¢	If a customer mentions suicide, self-harm, or hints at thoughts of ending their life,
References to Significant Health Events
â€¢	They mention a recent major health event, such as surgery, hospitalisation, or a new serious diagnosis, impacting their ability to meet financial obligations.
â€¢	Statements like â€œI just got out of the hospitalâ€ or â€œIâ€™ve been dealing with a serious health issueâ€ can serve as indicators.
Bereavement
â€¢	The customer mentions experiencing the recent loss of a loved one, which could impact their emotional and financial stability.
â€¢	Statements like â€œIâ€™m struggling after the loss of [family member]â€ or â€œIâ€™ve just lost someone close to meâ€ are strong indicators of vulnerability.
Family or Caregiver Involvement
â€¢	A family member or caregiver emails on behalf of the customer, explaining that the customer has health or cognitive issues affecting their ability to manage the account.
â€¢	The customer mentions they need someoneâ€™s help due to health-related challenges, signalling potential vulnerability.
Step 2 : Implement and Monitor Breathing Space
Income and Expenditure Form:
â€¢	Send  a copy of the income and expenditure form to the customer at the start of the 14-day hold.
â€¢	Request evidence, where appropriate,  of any change in circumstances (e.g., job loss, reduced income).
Hold Collections Activities: 
â€¢	Pause collections activities for the initial 14-day breathing space period and move the account to a new stage labelled " On Hold - Pending Evidenceâ€
Customer Communication: 
â€¢	Send  confirmation Email - Account on Hold for 14 Days with Request for Evidence and I&E Completion or Email - Account on Hold for 14 Days with Request to Complete I&E Only (as appropriate) to the customer confirming they are in a hold stage and set a follow-up date for the 14-day review. 
Step 3: Review and Extend if Necessary	
Breathing Space Review: 
â€¢	Before the end of the initial 14-day period, assess the customerâ€™s financial situation based on the income and expenditure form and any additional evidence provided. 
â€¢	Note: If at this stage the customer is deemed to be financially vulnerable, then please refer the account to a line manager who will determine whether or not a vulnerability flag should be added to the account
Follow-Up for Unreturned Forms: 
â€¢	If the customer has not returned their income and expenditure form within the 14 days, contact them to remind them of the request, send  Chaser Email for Evidence and I&E Request or Chaser Email for I&E Completion Only (as appropriate) . Provide an additional 14 days for them to return the form. Send a second chaser email at 21 days Second Chaser Email for Evidence and I&E Request (Sent at 21 Days) or Second Chaser Email for I&E Completion Only (Sent at 21 Days)
Step 4: Closure
End Breathing Space:
â€¢	If the customerâ€™s financial position has improved or a repayment plan can be agreed based the income and expenditure provided by the customer conclude the breathing space period, move the account out of the " On Hold - Pending Evidence " stage, and outline next steps for resuming payments.
Unreturned Income and Expenditure: 
â€¢	If the requested completed income and expenditure form or evidence of change in circumstances is not received within the extended 14-day period, return the account to the normal collections workflow and send Email - Hold Expired, Account Returning to Arrears Flow to the customer advising that the breathing space period has ended.

documents.title: Breathing Space Workflow - Health or Mental Health
documents.content:
Step 1: Identify Eligibility for Breathing Space
Trigger Event: 
â€¢	Customer discloses is identified or discloses as health or mental health vulnerable.
Step 2 : Implement and Monitor Breathing Space
Debt and Mental Health Evidence Form: For cases indicating mental health vulnerability:

Customer Communication:

Step 3: Review and Extend if Necessary
Breathing Space Review: 
â€¢	Before the end of the initial 30-day period, assess the customerâ€™s situation based on the DMHEF,  income and expenditure form and any additional evidence provided. 
Follow-Up for Unreturned Forms: 
â€¢	If the customer has not returned their income and expenditure form within the 30 days, contact them to remind them of the request. Send  30-Day Chaser Email - Reminder â€“ Supporting Information Needed for Your Account.  Provide an additional 30 days for them to return the information. Send a second chaser email at 45 days 45-Day Chaser Email - Final Reminder â€“ Supporting Information Needed to Continue Account Hold Continued Vulnerability Assessment: 
â€¢	The Vulnerability Specialist will reassess serious mental health cases to determine if additional support (such as an extended forbearance plan, write off) is needed.
Step 4: Closure
End Breathing Space:
â€¢	If the customerâ€™s position has improved, conclude the breathing space period, move the account out of the " Stage: On Hold - Vulnerable " stage, and outline next steps for resuming payments.
Unreturned Income and Expenditure:

documents.title: TEXAS - Vulnerable Customers
documents.content:
TEXAS is a widely used model designed to help frontline staff identify and respond appropriately to signs of customer vulnerability during conversations â€” especially when disclosures are made.

Each letter in TEXAS represents a step to guide the interaction:

ðŸ”¹ T â€“ Thank the customer
Acknowledge and thank the customer for sharing something personal. This builds trust and shows empathy.
Example:
"Thank you for letting me know, I really appreciate you sharing that with me."

ðŸ”¹ E â€“ Explain how the information will be used
Let the customer know why you're asking certain questions and how the information will help. This encourages openness and reassures them their data is handled appropriately.
Example:
"This is just so we can understand your situation better and make sure we support you in the right way."

ðŸ”¹ X â€“ eXplicit consent
Get clear permission to record and use the information disclosed, especially if it will impact how their account is handled.
Example:
"Is it okay if I make a note of what you've told me today so we can make sure your account reflects the right level of support?"

ðŸ”¹ A â€“ Ask relevant questions
Ask only appropriate, respectful follow-up questions to better understand their needs â€” without probing unnecessarily.
Focus on the impact, not the condition.
Example:
"How is this currently affecting your ability to manage your account or make payments?"

ðŸ”¹ S â€“ Signpost or support
Offer appropriate support based on what theyâ€™ve shared â€” this could include:

Applying collections hold or breathing space

Referring to the vulnerabilities specialist (Zoe Quick)

Offering adjusted communication or repayment options

Signposting to external organisations (e.g. Mind, StepChange, Samaritans)

âœ… Use TEXAS when:
A customer discloses a mental health, financial, or life-impacting condition.

You suspect vulnerability based on what they say, how they say it, or how they behave.

You want to build a complete picture before applying any account-level support or escalation.

documents.title: What is the cooling-off period?
documents.content:
The cooling-off period is a set amount of time that must pass between loans once a previous loan has been repaid. During this time, any new applications will be automatically declined, in line with our repeat lending policy.
The following applies:
â€¢	Between the 1st and 2nd loan â€“ 30-day cooling-off period
â€¢	Between the 2nd and 3rd loan â€“ 30-day cooling-off period

documents.title: What is Bankruptcy?
documents.content:
Bankruptcy is a legal process designed to help individuals who canâ€™t repay their debts. It gives you a fresh financial start by writing off most of your unsecured debts, but it also comes with serious consequences and restrictions.

ðŸ“ How do you apply?
In the UK, you can apply for bankruptcy online through the governmentâ€™s Insolvency Service. You donâ€™t need to go to court unless someone else is making you bankrupt. Itâ€™s a big decision, so itâ€™s important to get advice before applying.

ðŸ’· How much does it cost?
As of now, it costs Â£680 to apply for bankruptcy. This fee must be paid before your application can be submitted, although payment plans may be available in some cases.

ðŸ‘¥ Who manages your bankruptcy?
Once your bankruptcy is approved, it is managed by an Official Receiver â€“ a person who works for the Insolvency Service. Theyâ€™ll review your finances and may take control of certain assets to help repay your debts. In some cases, a Trustee may also be appointed to handle this.

âš ï¸ What restrictions does bankruptcy create?
When you're bankrupt, there are several restrictions you must follow, including:

You canâ€™t borrow more than Â£500 without telling the lender youâ€™re bankrupt.

You canâ€™t act as a company director without court permission.

You must cooperate fully with the Official Receiver and provide any information they request.

Your credit file will show the bankruptcy for 6 years, which can make getting credit, renting, or even some jobs more difficult.

Your assets may be sold, and you could be asked to make monthly payments for up to 3 years if you have disposable income.

ðŸ“Œ Important: Bankruptcy can be life-changing, so itâ€™s always best to speak to a free debt adviser before applying. They can help you explore all your options and make the best choice for your situation.

documents.title: What happens if a customer goes bankrupt?
documents.content:
Youâ€™ll be notified
If a customer is made bankrupt, youâ€™ll usually receive a notice from the Official Receiver or see it on the Insolvency Register. Alterntively, the customer may make you aware directly.

Stop all contact and collection
You must stop chasing the customer for payment â€” no calls, emails, letters, or legal action. Bankruptcy protection means you're legally not allowed to pursue the debt.

Send a Proof of Debt
You can submit a claim to the Official Receiver (or Trustee) showing how much youâ€™re owed, with any evidence (like statements or contracts).

Wait for updates
The Receiver will deal with the customerâ€™s assets. If thereâ€™s money left after priority debts and fees, you might get a small payment (called a dividend), though this is rare.

Debt is written off
After 12 months, bankruptcy usually ends. Most unsecured debts (like loans or credit cards) are written off. You canâ€™t chase the customer after this.

documents.title: How can a customer stop the default notice being registered on thier credit file?
documents.content:
To prevent the default notice from being recorded with the credit reference agencies, the customer must either:

Settle the balance stated in the letter by the date noted in the default notice. (Note: the balance in the letter may differ from the current outstanding balance, as interest has accrued since the letter was issued.)

documents.title: Debt Relief Order
documents.content:
A Debt Relief Order (DRO) is a formal insolvency tool designed for individuals with low income, minimal assets, and relatively small unsecured debts who are unable to repay their creditors. DROs provide a structured mechanism for managing qualifying debts while offering a clear path to debt write-off.

Key Features:

Debt Eligibility: Unsecured debts, including credit cards, personal loans, overdrafts, utility arrears, and other qualifying debts. Current debt limit: Â£30,000 (England & Wales).

Eligibility Criteria:

Total qualifying debts â‰¤ Â£30,000

Limited assets (generally no more than Â£2,000, excluding certain essential items)

Low disposable income (typically less than Â£75 per month after essential outgoings)

Must not have had a DRO in the past six years

Duration: Standard DRO period is 12 months. If circumstances remain unchanged, qualifying debts are written off at the end of this period.

Credit Impact: DROs remain on the individualâ€™s credit file for six years, affecting future credit applications.

Application Process:

Must be completed through an approved intermediary (debt adviser from an approved organisation).

A one-off fee of Â£90 is payable before submission.

Effect During DRO: Creditors included in the DRO cannot pursue repayment while the order is active.

Considerations for Staff:

DROs are suitable only for those meeting strict eligibility criteria; staff should verify circumstances carefully.

While DROs provide debt relief, they have long-term implications for the customerâ€™s credit rating and financial options.

Staff should advise customers of alternative solutions if DROs are not appropriate.

documents.title: Handling Customer DRO Notifications
documents.content:
Purpose:
To ensure customer Debt Relief Orders (DROs) are recorded accurately and accounts are managed correctly in line with our internal processes and regulatory requirements.

Procedure:

Customer Notification:

If a customer contacts us to advise they have been approved for a DRO, the agent should:

Record the DRO reference number.

Record the DRO order date.

Record the official receiver or intermediary handling the DRO.

Verification:

If the DRO has been formally made, the agent must verify it on the Insolvency Service Register:

Insolvency Service Register

Copy and paste the verification information into the customer notes.

Account Management:

Move the account to the IVA/Bankruptcy stage in the system.

A task will automatically be raised for the Back Office team to action at a later date.

Notes:

Ensure all relevant information is recorded clearly in the customer notes.

Do not attempt to take further collection action on accounts under an active DRO.

Outcome:
Following this procedure ensures compliance, accurate record-keeping, and that the customerâ€™s account is managed appropriately while under a DRO.

documents.title: Calculating Daily Interest
documents.content:
Purpose:
To provide staff with a clear process for explaining how interest is applied and to calculate the daily interest charge for customer accounts.

Interest Rate:

We charge 0.8% per day on the outstanding principal balance.

Daily Interest Calculation:

Identify the outstanding principal on the customer account.

Multiply the principal by 0.8% (0.008) to calculate the daily interest charge.

Formula:

Daily Interest = Outstanding Principal Ã— 0.008


Example Calculations:

Principal (Â£)	Daily Interest (Â£)
300	            2.40
500	            4.00
750	            6.00
1,000	        8.00
1,500	        12.00

Using the Table/Formula on Calls:

If a customer asks how much interest will be applied each day, staff can either:

Use the table for quick reference, or

Apply the formula to calculate the exact amount for the outstanding balance.

Notes:

Interest is calculated daily based on the current outstanding principal.

Do not include previously accrued interest when calculating daily interest â€” only use the current principal.

Ensure all calculations and explanations are clearly noted in the customer account.

documents.title: Early Settlements
documents.content:
Purpose:
To explain how early settlements work and provide staff with a clear process to follow when customers request to pay their loan in full before the end of the agreed duration.

Key Points:

Customers can settle their loan early by paying:

The outstanding principal, and

The interest accrued up to the settlement date.

The settlement figure provided is valid only on the day it is quoted.

If payment is not made on the same day, the settlement figure will increase daily at a rate of 0.8% of the outstanding principal.

Advise the customer:

â€œThis figure is valid for today only. If payment is not made today, the settlement figure will increase tomorrow by 0.8% of the outstanding principal.â€

Note the account with the settlement figure given and the date.

Formula for Daily Settlement Increase:

Daily Increase = Outstanding Principal Ã— 0.008


Example:

Outstanding principal: Â£1,000

Daily increase: Â£1,000 Ã— 0.008 = Â£8.00

If the customer does not pay today, the quoted settlement figure will increase by Â£8.00 tomorrow.

Important Notes for Staff:

Always remind customers that early settlement saves them from paying further future interest, but the figure changes daily.

Ensure all settlement quotes and customer communications are recorded in the notes.

Do not attempt to fix a settlement figure beyond the day it is quoted.

documents.title: Contacting Customers in Insolvency
documents.content:
No. Once a customer has entered an approved form of insolvency (e.g. Debt Relief Order, Individual Voluntary Arrangement, Bankruptcy, or Debt Management Plan through an appointed provider), we must not work directly with the customer regarding repayment of their debt.

Procedure for Staff:

Identify Insolvency Status:

Confirm the form of insolvency (e.g. DRO, IVA, Bankruptcy, DMP).

Record all relevant details in the customer notes (reference number, order date, name of Insolvency Practitioner/Official Receiver/DMP provider).

Verification:

Where applicable, verify on the Insolvency Register:
Insolvency Service Register

Copy and paste confirmation into customer notes.

Account Handling:

Move the account to the IVA/Bankruptcy stage in the system.

A back-office task will automatically be raised for further handling.

Communication:

Do not discuss repayment or collection directly with the customer.

Politely explain that all communications will now be managed via their appointed Insolvency Practitioner/Official Receiver/DMP provider.

Script Example for Agents:

â€œAs your account is now under an approved form of insolvency, weâ€™re not able to discuss repayment directly with you. From this point forward, all matters will be handled by your Insolvency Practitioner/Official Receiver, and we will work directly with them on your account.â€

Key Compliance Note:
Contacting customers directly to seek repayment after insolvency has been approved may breach regulatory obligations and consumer duty principles. All communication must go through the appointed insolvency representative.

documents.title: Insolvency Orders Made Before Loan Approval
documents.content:
Scenario:
A customer advises (or it is identified) that they had an insolvency order (e.g. DRO, IVA, Bankruptcy) in place before they took out the loan.

Key Point:

If the insolvency order was already made before the loan agreement was taken out, the customerâ€™s current loan is not included in that insolvency.

This means the customer remains liable for repayment under the original loan terms.

Procedure for Staff:

Check the insolvency order date against the loan start date.

If the insolvency order date is before the loan start date â†’ the loan is not covered by that order.

If the insolvency order date is after the loan start date â†’ follow the normal insolvency procedure (treat the loan as covered).

Record Details:

Note the insolvency order reference, date, and type in the account.

Record the loan start date for clarity.

Customer Communication:

If the loan is not covered by the insolvency order, explain clearly to the customer that the debt remains payable in full.

Example script:

â€œI can see that your insolvency order was made before this loan agreement started. This means your loan with us is not included in that arrangement, and you remain responsible for repayment under the original terms.â€

Account Handling:

Continue managing the loan as normal (collections, interest, or settlement discussions) unless the customer later enters into a new insolvency arrangement that includes this loan.

Compliance Note:
It is important to distinguish between debts included in insolvency orders and those that fall outside due to being taken out afterwards. Always double-check dates and record them clearly.

documents.title: Customer Service Essentials
documents.content:
Purpose: Ensure all staff interact with customers in a professional, supportive, and compliant way.

documents.title: Handling Difficult Conversations
documents.content:
Purpose: To support staff when customers become upset, angry, or frustrated.

Top Tips:

Stay calm and professional â€” donâ€™t match the customerâ€™s tone.

Acknowledge their feelings: â€œI can hear youâ€™re frustrated, letâ€™s work through this together.â€

If the customer becomes abusive, politely warn them before ending the call.

Always record notes factually and without judgment.

documents.title: Understanding & Managing Customer Vulnerabilities
documents.content:
Purpose:
To help staff recognise and respond appropriately when customers disclose vulnerabilities, in line with Consumer Duty and treating customers fairly.

1. Health-Related Vulnerabilities

Examples: Physical disability, serious illness, mental health conditions, addiction, cognitive impairment.

How to Respond:

Show empathy and patience.

Offer to slow down the call or provide information in writing.

If needed, place account into VUL (Vulnerability) status.

Provide signposting to specialist support (e.g. debt charities, mental health helplines).

2. Financial Vulnerabilities

Examples: Job loss, reduced income, high cost of living, reliance on benefits, sudden financial shock (e.g. bereavement, separation).

How to Respond:

Explore affordable solutions (payment plans, short-term hold).

Place into On Hold stage if evidence is pending.

Remind them about free, impartial debt advice services.

Record notes clearly with context.

3. Situational Vulnerabilities

Examples: Bereavement, domestic abuse, caring responsibilities, divorce/separation, homelessness.

How to Respond:

Be sensitive to emotional impact.

Avoid pressing for immediate decisions.

Offer flexibility and note the account accordingly.

Escalate if safeguarding concerns arise (e.g. risk of harm).

4. Communication Barriers

Examples: Low literacy, English not first language, hearing or speech difficulties, limited access to digital tools.

How to Respond:

Adapt communication style â€” speak clearly, avoid jargon.

Offer alternative formats (email instead of phone, written confirmation).

Allow extra time on calls.

Record any preferences in account notes.

5. Age-Related Vulnerabilities

Examples: Elderly customers with reduced memory/understanding, very young customers with limited financial experience.

How to Respond:

Check understanding by asking the customer to repeat back.

Provide extra explanations where needed.

Be mindful of potential safeguarding concerns.

Escalate if exploitation or financial abuse is suspected.

6. Risk of Harm / Safeguarding

Examples: Suicidal thoughts, domestic abuse, threats of violence, immediate safety risks.

How to Respond:

Stay calm and listen.

If risk of immediate harm, follow emergency safeguarding procedure (e.g. contact emergency services if disclosure suggests life is in danger).

Escalate to a manager straight away.

Record facts only, not opinions.

Key Staff Reminders

Always note the vulnerability in the system using MUST READ NOTE and/or place into On Hold-Vulnerble stage, with the reason stated clearly.

Never judge or dismiss what the customer discloses.

Provide reassurance and explain what support options are available.

Escalate if unsure â€” better to check than mishandle a vulnerable customer.

documents.title: Vulnerabilities & Tools for Staff
documents.content:
Purpose:
To help staff identify, record, and manage customer vulnerabilities consistently and sensitively, using recognised industry tools.

1. Health-Related Vulnerabilities

Examples: Long-term illness, disability, mental health, addiction.

Tool: TEXAS Protocol (for handling disclosures)

Thank the customer for sharing.

Explain how the information will be used.

Xplicit consent â€” ask if you can record/share it internally.

Ask relevant questions (how it affects finances, any support needed).

Signpost to help (e.g. StepChange, Mind, Citizens Advice).

2. Financial Vulnerabilities

Examples: Job loss, reduced income, benefit reliance, cost-of-living pressures.

Tool: IDEA (for understanding impact)

Impact â€” how is the situation affecting them financially?

Duration â€” is it short-term, long-term, or permanent?

Experience â€” have they managed something similar before?

Adjustment â€” what support or changes do they need?

3. Situational Vulnerabilities

Examples: Bereavement, caring duties, domestic abuse, separation.

Tool: CARERS (for carers or dependent-related issues)

Check circumstances sensitively.

Assess how caring impacts finances/time.

Record disclosure with consent.

Explain available support.

Refer to advice organisations if appropriate.

Support flexibly (e.g. pauses, payment plans).

documents.title: Using IDEA with Customers
documents.content:
Purpose:
IDEA helps agents understand the customerâ€™s situation more deeply when they disclose a vulnerability. It breaks the conversation into four areas: Impact, Duration, Experience, Adjustment.

I â€“ Impact

What impact is the vulnerability having on their finances or ability to manage the account?

âœ… Example questions:

â€œHow is this situation affecting your ability to make payments right now?â€

â€œHas this change impacted your income or expenses?â€

âœ… Example notes:

Customer unable to work due to surgery, now on reduced sick pay.

Customerâ€™s mental health makes budgeting difficult.

D â€“ Duration

Is the situation temporary, long-term, or permanent?

âœ… Example questions:

â€œDo you expect this to change soon, or is it ongoing?â€

â€œHas your GP or adviser said how long you may be in this situation?â€

âœ… Example notes:

Customer expects to return to work in 3 months after recovery.

Customer has long-term disability, likely ongoing.

E â€“ Experience

Has the customer been through this before, and how did they manage?

âœ… Example questions:

â€œHave you had to manage something like this before?â€

â€œWhatâ€™s helped you cope with your finances in the past?â€

âœ… Example notes:

Customer has been through redundancy before, relied on payment holidays.

Customer has never been in financial difficulty before, feels anxious and unsure.

A â€“ Adjustment

What changes, support, or solutions are needed now?

âœ… Example questions:

â€œWhat would help make things more manageable for you right now?â€

â€œWould a short-term hold or reduced payment plan give you some breathing space?â€

âœ… Example notes:

Customer requests 2-month payment hold until benefits start.

Customer would like smaller instalments for 6 months.

Putting It All Together â€“ Example Call Notes

IDEA applied:

Impact: Customer off work due to broken leg, income dropped to statutory sick pay.

Duration: Doctor says recovery expected in 12 weeks.

Experience: Customer previously managed using savings, but has none left now.

Adjustment: Customer requests a temporary hold on payments until return to work.

documents.title: Using CARERS with Customers
documents.content:
Purpose:
The CARERS tool helps agents handle disclosures where customers are carers, or where caring responsibilities are affecting their finances and account management.

C â€“ Check circumstances sensitively

Understand the customerâ€™s caring situation without being intrusive.

âœ… Example questions:

â€œCan I ask a little more about your caring responsibilities, so I can understand how it affects your account?â€

â€œWho do you provide care for, and how much time does this take each day?â€

âœ… Example notes:

Customer caring full-time for elderly parent with dementia.

Customer provides part-time care for disabled child alongside work.

A â€“ Assess how caring impacts finances/time

Does caring reduce income, increase expenses, or affect their ability to make payments?

âœ… Example questions:

â€œDoes your caring role affect your ability to work or manage finances?â€

â€œDo you have extra costs linked to caring, such as travel or equipment?â€

âœ… Example notes:

Customer reduced to part-time work due to caring role.

Customer has increased household costs, no spare income.

R â€“ Record disclosure with consent

Always ask before noting sensitive details.

âœ… Example script:

â€œWould you be happy for me to make a note of this on your account, so we can make sure we support you properly?â€

âœ… Example notes:

Consent given. Recorded customer caring for disabled child; limited availability during working hours.

E â€“ Explain available support

Tell the customer how we can help manage their account fairly.

âœ… Example script:

â€œWe can look at putting your account on hold, adjusting your payment plan, or finding a schedule that works around your circumstances.â€

R â€“ Refer to advice organisations if appropriate

Signpost to specialist support.

âœ… Examples:

Carers UK (www.carersuk.org
)

Citizens Advice

Local authority carersâ€™ services

âœ… Example script:

â€œThere are organisations that can support carers with financial and emotional help â€” would you like me to share their details?â€

S â€“ Support flexibly

Put in place adjustments to help the customer manage.

âœ… Examples:

Place account into On Hold (VUL) while circumstances are reviewed.

Offer flexible repayment dates that match benefit/payment cycles.

Allow more time for evidence if requested.

Putting It All Together â€“ Example Call Notes

CARERS applied:

Check: Customer provides daily care for disabled spouse.

Assess: Reduced working hours, lower income, increased household costs.

Record: Consent given; noted in account.

Explain: Advised account could be placed on hold pending review.

Refer: Provided details for Carers UK.

Support: Account placed into VUL stage; repayment plan to be reviewed in 3 months.

documents.title: What is an Annual Percentage Rate (APR)
documents.content:
What is APR?
APR stands for Annual Percentage Rate. It represents the total cost of borrowing over a year, including interest and any compulsory fees, expressed as an annual percentage of the amount borrowed.

Why Do We Use It?
Although our products are short-term and interest is typically calculated on a daily basis, we are still required by regulation to display an APR. This ensures transparency and consistency across all lenders, allowing customers to compare the cost of credit between different products and providers â€” even if the borrowing period is much shorter than a year.

How It Relates to High-Cost Short-Term Credit (HCSTC):

In high-cost short-term lending, the APR appears very high because itâ€™s an annualised figure based on daily interest rates applied to short borrowing periods.

For example, a loan that runs for 30 days with daily interest may look disproportionately high when shown as an annual rate, but this doesnâ€™t mean the borrower is paying that amount â€” itâ€™s simply how the cost is standardised for comparison.

The key figure for our customers remains the total amount repayable and the daily interest rate, which reflect the true short-term cost of borrowing.

In Summary:
We calculate interest daily to reflect short borrowing terms, but we must display the APR to comply with consumer credit regulations and maintain transparency for customers.

documents.title: Where can I locate the Annual Percentage Rate (APR)
documents.content:
Locating the APR Figure

You may receive questions from customers about where to find the APR (Annual Percentage Rate). The location depends on whether the customer is making a general enquiry or already has an active account.

1. General Public / Customer Service Enquiry

For general queries from potential customers who do not yet have an account, the APR can be found on our website.

At the bottom of the website, we display a representative example showing a typical loan and its associated costs:

Example:
Borrow Â£350 and pay Â£127.28 per month for 5 months at a fixed interest rate of 0.8% per day (292% per year).
The total charge for credit is Â£286.40 (all interest).
The total amount repayable is Â£636.40.
Representative APR: 1297.89%.

This example helps customers understand the cost of borrowing and how the APR relates to our short-term lending model.

2. Existing Customers with an Account

If the customer already has an account with us, the exact APR and full loan details are available within their Consumer Credit Agreement.

This document can be found in the customerâ€™s account area under â€œAttachments.â€
You should guide the customer to this section and explain that the agreement outlines their specific loan terms, including:

The interest rate

The total charge for credit

The total amount repayable

The representative APR

documents.title: What is a Notice of Sum in Arrears
documents.content:
A Notice of Sum in Arrears is a formal letter sent by a lender/creditor when a borrower has fallen behind on their repayments for a credit agreement regulated by the Consumer Credit Act (for example: loans, credit cards, hire purchase, store cards).

The notice is issued when the borrower has missed the equivalent of two or more payments, or has underpaid to the point that the arrears reach the value of two full instalments.

Its purpose is to:

Inform the borrower that they are behind on payments

Confirm the total amount of arrears owed

Explain any consequences, such as further action if the arrears are not cleared

Provide required information and protections, including where to get free debt advice

It is a statutory notice, meaning the creditor must send it. It is not a court order and does not mean legal action has already started.

documents.title: What is a Further Notice of Sum in Arrears?
documents.content:
A Further Notice of Sum in Arrears is a follow-up letter a lender/creditor must send after they have already issued an initial Notice of Sum in Arrears (NOSIA) under the Consumer Credit Act.

A further NOSIA is sent every six months if:

The borrower still has arrears outstanding, and

The credit agreement is still active.

Its purpose is to:

Update the borrower on how much arrears remain

Remind them that the account is still behind on payments

Provide the required statutory information, including consumer rights and where to access free debt advice

Just like the initial NOSIA, a further NOSIA:

Is not a court order

Does not mean legal action has begun

Is a legal requirement for regulated credit agreements

It is simply a periodic reminder that arrears are still owed.

documents.title: What is a Summary of Borrowing
documents.content:
A Summary of Borrowing (SOB) is a regulatory document a lender must provide to a customer who has taken a High-Cost Short-Term Credit (HCST) product (for example, payday or other short-term, high-cost loans). It gives a clear, concise breakdown of how much the customer has borrowed and how much they have paid in charges (interest and fees) over a reporting period.

Purpose:

Show the total amount borrowed during the reporting period.

Show the total charges (interest, fees, and other costs).

Improve transparency so customers can see the true cost of repeat or short-term borrowing.

Help customers make informed decisions about future borrowing and seek debt advice if needed.

Key points:

The SOB is informational only â€” it is not a collection notice or enforcement action.

It is a regulatory requirement designed to protect consumers and ensure visibility of repeated HCST borrowing.

When a customer SHOULD be sent an SOB

A lender must send a Summary of Borrowing:

Every three months (quarterly), in arrears, covering the previous three-month period â€” regardless of whether payments are due or the account is active, where the customer has had HCST borrowing that meets the FCA reporting criteria.

When the account is closed (including where the debt is sold or transferred to another creditor/third party).

Where there has been repeat borrowing from the lender (i.e., the customer has borrowed more than once), or otherwise where the FCAâ€™s HCST reporting criteria apply.

documents.title: What is our appeals process?
documents.content:
The appeal is reviewed by a senior underwriter to determine whether the original lending decision was correct.

The process typically takes up to 48 hours from the time the appeal is submitted.

To submit an appeal, the customer must follow the instructions in their decline email. In short, they should:

Email underwriting@ticktockloans.com

Clearly state their concerns and reasons for requesting a review

The senior underwriter will consider the customerâ€™s points as part of their review.

Appeal decisions will be communicated via email.

Customers can submit an appeal either directly by email or manually through a customer service representative.

documents.title: Outbound Dialling Guidelines
documents.content:
When handling outbound dialling, please follow these rules to remain compliant with our Arrears Collections policy:

Call Spacing & Attempt Limits

Leave at least 3 hours between the first and second call to the same customer.

Make no more than 5 call attempts per customer per day.

Voicemail Policy

Leave only one voicemail per customer per day.

Once a voicemail has been left, do not contact the customer again until the following day.

Due Calls

Call twice per day, once in the AM and once in the PM.

List Priority

First list: This is your initial priority for calling.

Second priority: DD + 1

Followed by: M0 â†’ M1 â†’ M2

Daily List Refresh

All lists are refreshed daily.

Inbound Call Priority

Inbound calls take priority between 9:00â€“10:00 AM and during lunch periods.

Resume outbound calls once these periods have ended.

documents.title: Call Structure â€“ Reminder Guide
documents.content:
1. Introduction

Introduce yourself and the company.

Complete DPA/security checks.

Advise the customer that calls are recorded (outbound calls).

2. Middle of the Call (Information Gathering)

Use open questions to understand the customerâ€™s situation:

â€œHow can I help you today?â€

â€œWhat has caused you to miss payments?â€

â€œHas anything changed in your circumstances recently?â€

â€œIs your situation likely to change in the near future?â€

â€œWhat steps are you taking to improve your situation?â€

Keep the conversation focused, supportive, and non-judgmental.

3. Resolution

Explore what the customerâ€™s situation allows them to do:

Do they need time to assess their finances or seek advice?

If they have income, how much can they reasonably pay toward their debt?

Can the customer make a realistic offer?

If not, consider completing an Income & Expenditure (I&E) with them.

Can they make a token payment during the call as a sign of goodwill?

Your aim is to reach a fair and sustainable solution based on their circumstances.

4. Call Closure

Before ending the call, confirm the following clearly:

The resolution/solution agreed

The terms (amounts, dates, frequency)

Whether an email will be sent confirming the arrangement

The consequences of not maintaining the arrangement, such as:

Issuing a pending default notice to credit reference agencies

Instructing a third-party debt recovery agency

Cancelling the arrangement and returning the account to collections

Set clear expectations:

Who will contact them

When they will be contacted

How we will communicate about upcoming payments or failed payments

Always close by asking:
â€œIs there anything else I can help you with today?â€

documents.title: What are the consequences of non-payment?
documents.content:
1. Arrangement Cancelled

If the customer misses a payment or breaks the terms of the plan:

The current payment arrangement will be cancelled.

The account will return to active collections, meaning further contact attempts may be made to resolve the arrears.

You should always tell the customer:

â€œIf the agreed payment is not made, the arrangement may be cancelled and your account will return to collections for further action.â€


2. Pending Default Notice Issued

If the account continues to remain unpaid:

A Pending Default Notice may be issued.

This is a formal warning that a default could be recorded if no action is taken.

It gives the customer an opportunity to bring the account back in line before a default is applied.

This should be explained clearly:

â€œIf the arrears are not resolved, we may issue a Pending Default Notice which is a formal step before a default is registered with credit reference agencies.â€


3. Default Registered with Credit Reference Agencies

If the customer still fails to contact us or make payments:

A default may be registered on their credit file.

This will remain on their credit report for six years.

It can affect their ability to obtain credit, mortgages, phone contracts, or other financial services.

Explain simply:

â€œA default can impact your credit rating for six years and may affect future borrowing.â€


4. Third-Party Debt Recovery Agency Instructed

If the account cannot be resolved directly:

The debt may be transferred to a licensed third-party debt recovery agency.

The customer will then be contacted by the agency, not us.

The agency may use their own contact processes to recover the balance.

Explain clearly and calmly:

â€œIf the account remains unpaid, it may be passed to a third-party debt recovery agency who will continue recovery efforts.â€


5. Additional Collections Activity

Depending on the customerâ€™s behaviour and account history, further action may include:

Increased outbound contact to try to engage the customer

Written correspondence outlining the arrears and next steps

Reassessment of the customerâ€™s affordability if they re-engage

These actions should always be proportionate, fair, and compliant with regulatory requirements.


6. Potential Legal Action (if applicable to your business)

If your organisation uses legal recovery routes, consequences may also include:

Escalation to the legal team for pre-legal assessment

The possibility of a County Court Judgment (CCJ)

Further enforcement if a CCJ remains unpaid

Only include this section if legal routes are used. If not, I can remove or adapt it.


7. Impact on Future Lending

If the customer continues to default or shows poor repayment behaviour:

They may be restricted from future borrowing

Their account may be flagged internally

They may be declined for new applications until the debt is resolved

Explain in simple terms:

â€œNon-payment can affect future lending decisions with us.â€

Summary to Read to Customers

Hereâ€™s a simplified version for agents to use during calls:

â€œIf the payment isnâ€™t made, the arrangement may be cancelled and your account will return to collections.
If it remains unpaid, we may issue a Pending Default Notice which can lead to a default being registered on your credit file for six years.
The account may also be passed to a third-party debt recovery agency.
Itâ€™s really important we work together to agree a plan that is realistic and sustainable for you.â€

documents.title: Can I change my password on my account?
documents.content:
Yes. You can update your password at any time by logging into your online account at www.ticktockloans.com.

Once logged in, go to the â€œMy Profileâ€ section, where you will be able to change your password to something more memorable and secure.

documents.title: Do you accept credit cards?
documents.content:
No. We do not accept credit cards as a payment method.

This is to ensure we comply with regulatory expectations, as customers should not use credit to repay credit, which could worsen their financial situation.

documents.title: Can I change the email address or phone number on theaccount?
documents.content:
Yes. You can update the contact details; however, for security reasons we must first speak to the customer on the mobile number currently registered on the account.

Once weâ€™ve verified the customers identity through that number, we can override the existing details and update the email address or phone number.

documents.title: Do we accept direct debit?
documents.content:
No 

Our primary automatic payment method is Continuous Payment Authority (CPA), which requires the customerâ€™s consent to allow payments to be collected automatically.

Customers can also choose manual collection, where they must call us to process each payment.

If a customer prefers to pay by other methods, bank transfer is available. However, this option cannot be used at the application stage, as CPA is required as part of the loan application process.

documents.title: What is a Subject Access Request (SAR)?
documents.content:
A Subject Access Request is a request made by an individual for access to the personal data an organisation holds about them.
SARs fall under the UK GDPR and Data Protection Act 2018.

A SAR can be:

Written (email, letter, webform)

Verbal (phone call, in person)

Made to any staff member â€” not just the Data Protection Officer

No special wording is required. If a customer says anything like â€œI want my dataâ€, it may be a valid SAR.

documents.title: Identifying a Valid SAR
documents.content:
A request is a SAR if the individual asks for:

â€œEverything you hold about meâ€

â€œAll my notes, calls, emails, recordingsâ€

â€œAny personal data you have on meâ€

â€œA copy of my informationâ€

If unsure, treat it as a SAR and escalate.

documents.title: DSAR (Data Subject Access Request) Process
documents.content:
Step 1 â€” Acknowledge the Request

Thank the customer and confirm that we can help.

Advise that we will need to log the request for processing.

If on a call, note that the request is verbal â€” this is still valid.

Step 2 â€” Raise the Correct Task

Agents must raise a Complaint â€“ Subject Access Request task.
This must be assigned to Alex Cross to action all DSAR responses.

This step is mandatory for every DSAR, regardless of channel or phrasing.

Step 3 â€” Inform the Customer of the Timescales

Provide the standard timeframe information:

We must respond within one month of receiving the request.

If the request is complex or involves large volumes of data, we may need to extend the deadline by up to two additional months.

If an extension is needed, the customer must be informed within the first month.

3. Identity Verification

Before data can be released, identity must be verified.
Follow our standard security checks.
If identity can't be safely confirmed, the timeframe is paused until verification is completed.

4. What Happens After the Task Is Raised

Handled by Alex Cross:

Logging the DSAR

Gathering all relevant data (notes, correspondence, call recordings, documents)

Reviewing and redacting where needed

Preparing the DSAR response pack

Sending securely to the customer

Closing the complaint task

Recording completion in the SAR log

Agents do not prepare, review, or send DSAR information themselves.

5. What to Avoid

Never refuse a request because itâ€™s verbal

Never send personal data directly

Never promise specific data points (e.g., â€œwe definitely have that call recordingâ€)

Never delay raising the task â€” the one-month timeframe starts immediately upon receipt

6. Standard Script Example (Optional for Agents)

â€œI can help with that. Iâ€™ll log a Subject Access Request for you today. We must respond within one month, and if the request is complex we may extend by up to two additional months â€” but we would let you know within the first month if thatâ€™s needed.â€
